displayed_text: Patient: I didn’t know that. Doctor: But, yeah, like when you fly- Patient: I was trying to- Doctor: Like when you fly to Europe, you kind of fly up over, like if you’re going to England, you fly up over Greenland and down. Patient: Yeah. That’s what they did. That’s exactly what they did. Doctor: It’s shorter somehow. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think like taking a globe and a string or something and see. Patient: Yeah. I didn’t understand why- Doctor: I don’t quite understand how it’s shorter, but it’s shorter. Family Member: But we could see on the plane, you know, on the screen the pattern he’s flying in- Doctor: Yeah. You go up. Right. You go up along Canada. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: And they would ask about the dose as well. So at any rate, to answer your question that the advise on the Metformin is if you have another reason to be on it. Patient: Yes. Doctor: For example, if you have a slight gluco-spasm where the glucose is a little bit elevated or if you have you know clinical type two diabetes. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Then it may also be beneficial for your prostate cancer, but the prostate cancer I wouldn’t say should be the primary reason for being on it. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And if you do go back on that program, which it sounds like you’ve already done on your own. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I would definitely encourage you to check in with your cardiologist if you still have one, just to make sure that he or she agrees with that. Patient: Uh hum, okay. Doctor: Uh that they don’t think that it’s unnecessary from a general medical perspective or from a perspective. Patient: Uh hum.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’ll request, I don't know if its available, but I hope it is; if it’s eight a.m., it will be earlier. Patient: That will be fine. Doctor: So that will be for the appointment itself. So we’ll sign that. And then the next step will be to order the PSA and the testosterone the week before Patient: Could you also include the um, my diabetes AC. Doctor: The A1C. Patient: Yes, A1C and I could just give them to my doctor. Doctor: Okay, so a week before would be the week of January eighth. I’m just going to click on that day and I’ll click on the boxes approximate, so it will be any day of the week of January eighth – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - and then I’ll click on LabCorp. Patient: Uh hum, can you do multiple orders or do just have to be one order. Doctor: Each one is separate, so you can have three different pieces of paper printed out. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that. Doctor: Oh, are you reading the consent? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, so you know what I mean. Doctor: Mmm. Didn’t they give you a bigger version before you go blind looking at your phone, because it's like 30 pages of that stuff- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: You want us to print it? Patient: Seven to twenty nine. Doctor: Yeah, it is, it is a mess. Patient: I haven't read it before. Doctor: I mean, most of it is, um, I say usual, you might get tired, because tired is always tops of everything. Patient: Mhm.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I know (sighs) Patient: Because I don’t mind making a phone call either but probably me stay out or what do you think? Doctor: Yeah it’s gonna be all how we code and get them… Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: So at this point anyway now that we’re in here now okay this is… Doctor: This is it. Family Member: So they’ll approve it probably the next Thursday? Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And then they’ll say oh the note says you’re off study this is standard run of the mill dose of taxo… oh you want to give Neulasta on day two because you’re worried about having compromise of your white cells, which is still a little you know not at the most robust, but your cell lines have- Patient: Sure. Doctor: - gone down because of the previous chemo. But look we have a great respond, so let’s just move on boys and girls. Doctor: And the then they’ll go oh that makes sense Stan and then you show up and then there we are. Patient: Yeah, okay, okay.

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Um, um unless you tell me J____ I know exactly what I want to do I want to go you know one way or the other. Patient: Adverse effects to radiation? (Laughs) Doctor: So radiation, radiation is an additional therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Clearly. It uses thermal energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Ahh to essentially sterilize the field that exposed to that… Patient: I’m sure it’s very pinpoint because my wife was over at the R ___. So, Doctor: It is, it is as precise as they can make it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s done you know the modeling that they use, the 3D mapping…

Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And at some point, everybody’s saying those will stop working or could stop working. Doctor: They could stop working. Um. They will stop working eventually. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I mean, usually, it takes a year or two. But, they will stop eventually. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Yeah. I hope that’s true. But my experience with these really expensive drugs is you’re going to get billed. Patient: Right. I was thinking the same thing. Doctor: Okay? So they will ask you then at our pharmacy, well, can you afford that amount of money, and if you can’t, so they will work to see if there’s grants to see whether they can, the drug companies who make these drugs, can cover the cost that you can’t cover. Okay? But you have to have Medicare D and all these other things. So it can take a little bit while depending on if they have it. And again, they’re going to do a wallet check to see how much you make to see what they think you can cover. Patient: Well, I’m working. Family Member: Well, right. Doctor: That, that’s just the rules that they’re going to go through. Family Member: I see. Doctor: Abiraterone is probably what I would prefer. Although for you, the downsides of it is potentially, you know, fluid retention. Huh, there is a lot of fatigue related to it. Huh, huh, we have to watch your blood tests a little bit. Huh, about seventy-five percent, three out of four people, their PSA is going to drop on it. Huh, the average person’s on it for about fifteen months, then the cancer figures it out, and we have to look at maybe moving to something else. We don’t change therapy based on PSA. We base it on how you’re feeling and whether your scans show more cancer than what we saw today. Okay? Patient: Now, what would you recommend right now? Doctor: Yeah. I, I like the abiraterone but we’ll have to check to sort of see what the cost is to you. The other one doesn’t need prednisone. It makes people a little bit more frail so I’m a little bit more worried about that one in you. Huh, you know, we don’t have right offhand a clinical trial that I can think about. Our first study with abiraterone, you have to have a mutation which you don’t have. So we would just be able to give you abiraterone. Our enzalutamide plus new drug first-line study is on hold right now. Huh, the two other studies that we have all require that you have had abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, so usually after one of these drugs if your cancer is getting worse more options from a clinical trial perspective open up. Huh, we just finished our study of radiation and a vaccine. We don’t know if that has any activity or working yet to see whether or not, huh, that would be a standard option. Huh, you aren’t eligible, so right now, it would be the abiraterone that we would head towards. So what I typically do is send an email to our pharmacy saying can you price this out, then speak to you about whether you can afford it or not afford it, and then, huh, they work on sort of the patient assistance program, if you need it. Huh, if you don’t need it or you get one of those things, then they can provide the drug. Huh, we might have you come in and meet with that pharmacist or one of the nurse practitioners that I work with, huh, to sort of just re-go over what you may feel with starting the new drug, or that if, again, we just can’t get it for you, we can try the other one, or we would think maybe even going to the radium, which is a liquid radiation drug, which is given here in the clinic. Usually that’s what we go to next. Patient: That’s what I had before but they, radia, huh- Doctor: Rad.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: They’re just taking it as uh pay as you go. Uh so we’ve talked before, and I know you have the means to do it. Uh they, so, I’d, I’d work with a group. There’s a group in Heidelberg, Germany, and there’s a group in a place called Bad Berka, which is, I could show it to you on a map, but it’s, it’s outside of Frankfurt. Patient: Um huh.. Doctor: It’s near, it’s in East Germany. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh those two groups have the biggest experience. The guy I know very well is in Bad Berka. Uh I think both groups though will take referrals, and then they take over and make the arrangements for folks to come, put you up, all the things. And the number they quoted me is about fifty-thousand bucks to do it. Um which by American standards, is incredibly cheap, but because you can’t get, take advantage of health insurance, you know. Patient: Yeah. It really is sort of out of pocket. Family Member: But he could do it right away? Doctor: He could potentially. I, I, at least I could contact my contact and find out. I also know the group in Heidelberg. We could find out. Uh the groups here, uh I don’t know the Cornell group and the group at UCLA. I don’t know. Those are trials. So they’re going to have eligibility. Patient: Do you think I’d be eligible for them? Doctor: I don’t know. I, I can look into it. Patient: Yeah. I -

Patient: When I was in the hospital checking every day - Doctor: Today your creatinine is one point zero. And your liver tests are all normal. Your PSA is pending; it looks like – Patient: They didn’t know. Doctor: It just hasn’t resulted yet. Family Member: Uh, the last reading when we were here on the twelfth of November, the reading was seventeen for PSA. Did that corrected? Doctor: Seventeen. Family Member: And the scale - is that improving or not or - Patient: Thirty-eight point six or thirty-eight. Family Member: I don’t know Doctor: It was forty-eight in July. Patient: Right. Doctor: And when I saw him on November seventh he had been on the pills for two weeks.

Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check. Patient: What kind of pills? Doctor: So these are FDA-approved pills called Xtandi, which is the trade name. Uh, they’re four pills once a day, and their primary goal of how they work is it’s, it’s like a big hormone pill again. So it’s to help your shot work better. It also is approved by the FDA because it helps you live longer. No cures. Same as we were before but we need to get a handle on all these things in the lung. In the same way, you’re also a candidate for chemo to tell you the truth. Uh, so chemo’s in the mix as well, but the majority of folks I think, and I’m not saying you do, but my patients tend to prefer pills before going on to chemotherapy, and I think way back when we initially again reconnected you were not in so much favor of chemo, uh, as he’s already shaking his head, but I want to bring that up again because at some point we may need to go to chemo. So I want to put that out there still. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but we do have a set of pills. Now, the good news is every time there’s an approved medication, you know, we’re at K______, so we do a lot of clinical studies. So one of our studies is to use that same medication and see if we add a second pill to half the group whether you’d respond better. So I like that study because it’s all pills and no one gets a placebo when you’re thinking about the Xtandi pills. Everyone is on the regular pill that is approved. The question of the placebo versus the other drug is extra. Okay? So I’m not sure if that makes sense or if you’ve got questions with that, but we’re going to try hard to have you be, you know, considered for that study. Uh, I want you to still recover well from your, your hospitalization, but, uh, but that’s in the works for us to consider. The other part is either way, however we move forward, there’s another study, which is a registry study, called, Iron Man. Uh, not that you become iron man- Patient: Hum. Doctor: but that all your experiences as to what’s happened to you get captured. And that means you write out and answer questionnaires. I write out and answer questionnaires. Uh, and then about once a year we take some blood to see what’s happening uh in terms of new research. Uh, and that participation’s pretty cool because a lot of other men around the world are, are participating. And so we get answers from guys from Australia, Ireland, uh, you know, England uh, gosh, Canada, France, so all of that. So everyone’s experience will be captured. And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger.

Patient: For how long? Doctor: Well that’s what the consent will give you the exact details Patient: Okay, Yeah. Doctor: of how many times a week, but the first few weeks typically are very, what this is called is a Phase I study. So it’s an earlier setting like I said the combination really we don’t have a good handle on what to expect in terms of toxicities, what dose, etc. So one of the side effects that has been noted so far is that the platelets can drop with this medication. So that is something of course the blood counts will be monitored anyway. Besides that kidney function, liver function, all that will also be monitored and checked. You go – undergo EKG monitoring that will be hard test like and echo before you start. So there is a lot of components. One additional component is that you probably will need to do a biopsy again as part of the study. Doctor: So that’s something to think about before you say yes or no. Patient: And does platelets dropping how would that affect me physically? Doctor: Well if it gets really low then it can cause bleeding and things like that - Family Member: Like internal? Doctor: -but the whole idea of this closed monitoring is to not let it get that far. But you know obviously if you notice any bleeding, nose bleeds, gum bleeds, blood in the urine, whatever I need to know right away. Family Member: But how about the bleeding that’s rectal bleeding that he’s having now. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, so has you know we’ll probably have to wait and see, but changes are that should respond to just medical management and will clear up. Family Member: Yeah and you know we had the colonoscopy and the… Doctor: Yeah

Patient: No. Doctor: And, huh, you’re by yourself today? Patient: Yeah. Um hum. Doctor: Huh, huh, so were you having double vision? Patient: No. But not- Doctor: Just the eye was getting too dry for the blink, it doesn’t blink? Patient: It doesn’t blink. The eye’s not going to blink. But, you know. Doctor: Did they scan your brain or anything? Patient: I did a, I did a, in my, huh, in my, in my eye hit at the Doctor: Because it’s gotten worse. Patient: What? Doctor: I mean, your face is even- Patient: Well, one thing, I said the wrong side. It’s not the right side. It’s the left side.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Any other questions? Patient: No. Like I say the PSA thing is, of course you know we were always brought up with that kind of… Doctor: I know, I know. Patient: And you understand it. Doctor: No I absolutely… Patient: And I just wondered you know with. Doctor: Yes. Yeah I agree with you. Patient: As far as, as far as… Doctor: It’s not a trivial issue by any means. Patient: But you know like I say with the PSA if it’s up and everything but the scans the CT scans are good I mean if they’re… Doctor: Yeah, so that’s a good situation to be in is what I’ll tell you. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Hum. Okay. Family Member: So between now and September fifth, a week-? Doctor: That’s, that’s two weeks. Yeah. Family Member: Does he go in for another blood transfusion or are you expecting the hemoglobin to increase pretty much on its own as he regulates without the medication? Doctor: One idea would be to check a hemoglobin level at a local laboratory, uh, one week from now just to see where we are at. And if it has made significant progress on its own, we can skip the blood transfusion. And if it looks like it’s only gone up like one-tenth of a point, then we can perhaps schedule a blood transfusion before September fifth. So if you agree to that, I can give you, uh, a prescription for a complete blood count. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Like next Tuesday or next Wednesday. But I think either way, because of this anemia that has come back, uh, the trial at the very least will require us to stop the medication until the hemoglobin increases. Patient: Hum. Family Member: So are there other things that he can do like, say, for instance, you know, maybe take an iron or, but are there food products that he can eat that might help with increasing, uh, his blood? Doctor: Well, there’s many, you know, causes for anemia. And the only one of them that is helped by iron is iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-deficiency anemia is typically, one, caused by bleeding from somewhere. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: So, uh, I really don’t think you have the iron-deficiency anemia, and so, uh, I don’t think that will help that much, unfortunately. You know? I wouldn’t discourage you from taking iron if you want to.
